Iterate over the four candidate cities (Boston, Chatham, Amherst, Ashburnham) and read each monthly_precipitations_<city>.csv file.
Keep only the 2015 row and the three summer-month columns (Jun, Jul, Aug); convert these month columns to float and sum them to obtain the total summer rainfall for that city.
Collect the four totals in a list/array and pick the city whose index corresponds to the extreme rainfall value that np.argmax returns (intended to identify the city to analyse further).
Filter the water-quality records so that only rows whose Community equals the chosen city (hard-coded as “Chatham” in the snippet) are retained.
Clean the Beach Name field by splitting on “@” and keeping only the first part to get a canonical beach name.
Group the filtered data by Beach Name to count total samples taken at each beach.
Within the same filtered set, isolate rows where the Violation column (converted to lower-case) equals “yes” and count those violations per beach.
Merge total-sample counts with violation counts, fill any missing violation counts with zero, and compute an exceedance (violation) rate for 2015 as Violations ÷ Total Samples.
Sort beaches by this exceedance rate in descending order; the first three entries of the sorted list represent the three most polluted beaches for the selected city.
